questions.question: All of the following are true about small bowel duplication except?

options.A: These are submucosa-lined structures in continuity with the GI tract
options.B: The most common site is the ileum
options.C: Cystic duplication is the most common type

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) These are submucosa-lined structures in continuity with the GI tract Intestinal Duplication: These are mucosa -lined structures in continuity with the GI tract (Option A) . Most common site - ileum (Option B) Contains all 3 layers Shares the common wall and vascular supply Located along the mesenteric border (Option D) Types of small bowel duplication: Cystic duplication: Tubular duplication: Most common - 75% cases (Option C) It does not communicate with the lumen of the small intestine Partial small bowel obstruction leads to: Recurrent abdominal pain Vomiting 25% cases Communicates with the lumen of the small intestine If the proximal part communicates: Proximal duplication . If the distal part communicates: Distal duplication . Presence of ectopic gastric mucosa (ileal ulcer) → acid production → ulcer → bleeding → hematochezia. Diagnosis: On USG - Triple layer effect is seen (characteristic appearance) IOC for diagnosis - CECT Tc-Pertechnetate scan in case of ectopic gastric mucosa. Treatment : For short segment duplication: Resection and anastomosis For long segment duplication: Multiple enterotomy with stripping of mucosa Division of common wall by stapler.

questions.question: A 10-day-old female baby was brought to the OPD with the following findings as shown in the image given below. On examination there is no cough impulse in the swelling. X-ray examination shows the erosion of the coccyx. The most likely clinical diagnosis would be:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sacrococcygeal teratoma Explanation: The given image showing a large mass in the sacrococcygeal region (lower back, near the tailbone) along with the X-ray showing erosion of the coccyx points toward the diagnosis of sacrococcygeal teratoma. Teratomas mostly occur during the neonatal period and most of them are benign Most common site- Sacrococcygeal region Females > males The risk of malignancy increases with age It is thought to be derivative of the primitive streak Clinical features: External presacral mass with minimal intrapelvic presacral component Symptoms include weakness, paralysis, and bladder or bowel dysfunction Currarino Triad: Anorectal malformations + sacrococcygeal osseous defect + presacral mass Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis CT/MRI is done to detect intra-abdominal and intra-pelvic components. Treatment: Complete surgical excision of the tumor should be done To avoid local recurrence - resection of the coccyx is done Spina bifida (Option A) : Typically presents with a midline defect in the spine but without erosion of the coccyx or a prominent cough impulse. Myelomeningocele (Option B) : Involves herniation of the meninges and spinal cord, usually in the lumbosacral region, but is not characterized by coccygeal erosion or a teratoma-like mass. Sacral agenesis (Option D): A developmental disorder characterized by the absence of parts of the sacrum but not typically associated with a mass or erosion of the coccyx.

questions.question: How will you manage a case of anorectal malformation with no visible fistula in a female patient with cross-table lateral X-ray showing rectum below the coccyx?

options.A: Protective colostomy followed by posterior sagittal anorectoplasty

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Protective colostomy followed by posterior sagittal anorectoplasty Explanation: The management of anorectal malformation varies based on sex and whether the lesion is high or low. For High lesions- Protective colostomy followed by Posterior Sagittal Anorectoplasty (PSARP) after 4-8 weeks. (Option A) For Low lesions- Only perineal anoplasty is performed Management protocol of ARM in males and females: Anoplasty (Option B) is the treatment of choice in perineal fistula Colostomy (Option C) In cases of no visible fistulae with cross-table lateral X-ray suggestive of high rectum, colostomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.question: Which of the following diagnostic methods is used to differentiate between a high and low lesion in anorectal malformation, and how does it determine the location of the rectum? pelvic floor.

options.A: Abdominal ultrasound; identifies the rectal location by imaging the entire pelvic cavity.
options.B: MRI of the pelvis; differentiates based on the presence of anatomical anomalies in the pelvic floor
options.C: Invertogram; assesses the rectal termination by the rise of gas in relation to the pelvic floor.
options.D: X-ray of the pelvis; determines rectal termination based on bone structures and distance from the

questions.explanation: pelvic floor. Correct Answer: C) Invertogram; assesses the rectal termination by the rise of gas in relation to the pelvic floor. Explanation: An invertogram is the diagnostic method used to differentiate between high and low lesions in anorectal malformation. Assessment Method: Invertogram is used to determine the rectal termination relative to the pelvic floor. This test is typically performed 6-12 hours after birth. A coin is placed at the location where the anus is expected, and the baby is positioned upside down for at least 3 minutes. The gas is going to rise at the distal part of the large intestine. High Lesion: The rectum ends above the Levator ani complex. Low Lesion: The rectum ends below the Levator ani complex. Abdominal ultrasound (Option A) does not specifically differentiate high vs. low lesions based on rectal termination relative to the pelvic floor. MRI of the pelvis (Option B) is not typically used for this specific diagnostic purpose in anorectal malformation. X-ray of the pelvis (Option D) does not accurately determine the rectal termination in relation to the pelvic floor.

questions.question: Which of the following accurately describes a component and a step involved in the LADD's operation for managing intestinal malrotation? abdomen

options.A: Appendectomy; Division of LADD’s bands near the medial aspect of the duodenum
options.B: Reduction of volvulus; Widening of the mesenteric base by mobilizing the duodenum
options.C: Bowel repositioning; Resection of viable bowel wrapped in warm, moist sponges
options.D: Division of LADD’s bands; Placement of the duodenum and proximal jejunum on the left side of the

questions.explanation: duodenum Correct Answer: B) Reduction of volvulus; Widening of the mesenteric base by mobilizing the duodenum Explanation: Reduction of Volvulus : This is a key component of the LADD's operation, which involves correcting the twisted bowel. Widening of the Mesenteric Base : During the procedure, the duodenum is mobilized and straightened by dividing the abnormal ligament of Treitz and LADD’s bands to prevent future volvulus. LADD's Operation Components : Reduction of Volvulus : Correcting the twisted bowel. Division of LADD's Bands : Cutting the fibrous bands that may cause obstruction. Appendectomy : Removing the appendix to prevent future diagnostic confusion. Positioning of the Intestine : Adjusting the placement of the intestines, with or without fixation. Steps : RUQ Transverse Incision : Making an incision across the right upper quadrant. Counter-Clockwise Rotation : Correcting the volvulus by rotating the bowel counter-clockwise. Bowel with Uncertain Viability : Wrapping potentially viable bowel in warm, moist sponges for at least 15 minutes. Resection of Gangrenous Bowel : Removing any necrotic bowel sections. (Option C) Division of LADD's Bands : Cutting the bands near the lateral side of the duodenum. (Option A) Widening of the Mesenteric Base : Mobilizing and straightening the duodenum by dividing the abnormal ligament of Treitz and LADD's bands. Appendectomy : Performing an appendectomy to avoid future diagnostic issues. Final Bowel Position : Duodenum and Proximal Jejunum : Positioned on the right side of the abdomen. (Option D) Terminal Ileum and Cecum : Positioned on the left side of the abdomen. (A) Bowel is assessed and, if volvulus is present, gently detorsed in a counterclockwise direction (arrow). (B) Ladd bands attaching the colon to the liver, gallbladder, or retroperitoneum are divided sharply or with electrocautery. (C) Adhesions to the mesentery are divided (arrows) and the mesenteric pedicle widened, allowing the colon to be placed on the left side of the patient and the small bowel with a straightened duodenum on the right. (D) Final position of the bowel contents at the completion of the Ladd procedure.

questions.question: A 3-week-old infant presents with sudden-onset bilious vomiting and lethargy. The baby has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain and has not been gaining weight as expected. On examination, the infant shows signs of poor perfusion and decreased urine output. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what should be the primary investigation to confirm it?

options.A: Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Upper GI Contrast Study
options.B: Pyloric Stenosis; Upper GI Contrast Study
options.C: Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Barium Swallow Study

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Intestinal Malrotation with Midgut Volvulus; Upper GI Contrast Study and metabolic acidosis suggests midgut volvulus , a serious complication of malrotation. Upper GI Contrast Study is the primary investigation to confirm malrotation. It allows visualization of the positioning of the duodenum and the ligament of Treitz and can identify midgut volvulus. Clinical Features of malrotation: Asymptomatic Cases : Malrotation can be discovered incidentally through radiological exams or during an autopsy when no symptoms are present. Symptomatic Cases : Without Volvulus : Symptoms include persistent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, and failure to thrive (inadequate weight gain). With Volvulus (Emergency Situation) : The primary symptom may be bilious vomiting, which can sometimes be the sole indication of midgut volvulus. Lethargy due to inadequate blood flow. Decreased urine output . Metabolic acidosis . Investigations: Laboratory Findings : Metabolic acidosis Thrombocytopenia Leucopenia Gold Standard for Diagnosis : The Upper GI Contrast Study is the preferred method for diagnosing malrotation. Barium Swallow : This test is not typically used for diagnosing malrotation because it does not effectively rule out malrotation (Option C and D) . Pyloric stenosis (Option B) presents in infants between 3-6 weeks of age and the vomiting is non-bilious because the obstruction is proximal to the duodenum. Additionally, the imaging investigation for pyloric stenosis is ultrasound , not an upper GI contrast study. An ultrasound would show the characteristic "olive sign" and pyloric muscle hypertrophy. Management For Acutely Ill Children with Peritonitis: Exploratory Laparotomy is performed as an emergency procedure. For Symptomatic Volvulus: Administer IV fluids and IV antibiotics. Decompress the proximal stomach. Proceed with emergency surgery. For Chronic Symptoms or Symptom-Free Patients: Plan for elective correction. The standard surgical approach is the LADD's procedure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about hyper-rotation of intestines?

options.A: The cecum is located in the left hypochondrium
options.B: The cecum is in the midline inferior to the pylorus
options.D: The presence of Ladd's bands is noticed

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The cecum is located in the left hypochondrium Explanation: Hyper-rotation occurs when there is excessive counter-clockwise rotation of the midgut beyond the 270° rotation. Due to this excessive rotation, the cecum, which normally ends up in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, may be displaced to the left upper quadrant (left hypochondrium) . This abnormal positioning is a direct result of the excessive rotation of the midgut. Types of rotational abnormalities: Rotational Abnormalit Description Abnormalities Non-Rotation Most common rotational abnormality. Failure of counter-clockwise rotation after return of midgut to the abdominal cavity. Duodenum (C-loop), Ligament of Treitz, and small intestine are on the right side. Cecum and large intestine are on the left side. Proximal jejunum and ascending colon fused as one pedicle. Incomplete Rotation Most common type of malrotation. Arrested counter-clockwise rotation around 180° (Option C) . Small intestine lies on the right side. DJ flexure located on the right side of the vertebral column. Duodenum may have a corkscrew configuration. Major part of the large intestine on the left side. Cecum is close to midline. Right colon located more medially. Failure of fixation of ascending colon in right hypochondrium, leading to narrow intestinal mesentery and presence of Ladd's bands. (Option D) Reverse Rotation Rotation occurs in a clockwise direction around the SMA. Duodenum is anterior to the superior mesenteric artery. Transverse colon is posterior to the superior mesenteric artery. Hyper-Rotation Counter-clockwise rotation greater than 270°. Cecum is located in the left hypochondrium (Option A) . Mixed Rotation Intestine does not rotate as it enters the abdomen after a physiological hernia. Cecum is located in the midline, inferior to the pylorus (Option B) . Increased risk of volvulus. Reference: SRB's Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page, 917.

questions.question: A 3-day-old male baby is brought with complaints of irritable crying. Mother gave the history of not passing meconium in the first 48 hours of life. On examination, abdominal distension was seen with rebound tenderness and reduced bowel sounds. Identify the condition.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Complicated meconium ileus Explanation: Meconium ileus is complicated by perforation in utero or just after birth. This leads to peritonitis. This results in: Dense inflammatory adhesions Calcification (snowstorm appearance in USG) Clinical features: Meconium pseudocyst Adhesive peritonitis with or without bacterial infection Ascites Diagnosis: X-ray Specks of calcification Dilated bowel loops Mass Effect On USG: Snowstorm appearance(characteristic finding) Management: For uncomplicated cases - Non-operative treatment like enemas with Gastrografin, N-acetylcysteine 10% solution for irrigation per-rectum, or via NG tube. In more severe or unresponsive cases, surgery is required. The standard surgical approach involves: Enterotomy (making an incision into the bowel) and irrigation with warm saline or 4% N-acetylcysteine to flush out meconium pellets. The bowel is then closed after complete evacuation of the meconium. If necessary, meconium pellets may be manually pushed into the large bowel. For critically ill patients, Bishop-Koop Operation: a proximal dilated bowel segment is resected and anastomosed (connected) to the distal collapsed ileum - ileostomy is done and is later closed when the patient's condition stabilizes. Santulli Operation: Proximal ileum is brought out as an ileostomy for irrigation, while the distal ileum is sutured to the proximal ileum through an end-to-side anastomosis . Sigmoid volvulus (Option B) occurs in older children, adolescents, or adults. It generally causes progressive abdominal distension, vomiting, and constipation, but it is not associated with the failure to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. Duodenal atresia (Option C) typically presents with bilious vomiting within the first few hours after birth, often associated with conditions like Down syndrome. Obstruction occurs proximally in the duodenum and is not associated with delayed meconium passage. Midgut volvulus (Option D) usually presents with bilious vomiting , abdominal pain, and signs of bowel ischemia. The hallmark of midgut volvulus is bilious vomiting rather than failure to pass stool and presents with more acute symptoms.

questions.question: At 2 days of life, a male newborn becomes irritable and inconsolable. He is noted to have abdominal distension. He failed to pass meconium since being born. A follow-up barium enema shows microcolon and terminal ileum with meconium. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Meconium ileus Explanation: In the given scenario, the child presented with abdominal distension and failed to pass meconium since birth. Additionally, barium enema showing microcolon and terminal ileum with meconium is suggestive of meconium ileus. Manifestation of simple meconium ileus include: Terminal ileum is dilated Thick, tar-like inspissated meconium in terminal ileum, which causes small bowel obstruction above Smaller pellets of meconium Relatively narrow colon Clinical features: Generalized abdominal distension Bilious vomiting Failure of passage of meconium Diagnosis: On X-ray: Dilated bowel loops are present, and air-fluid levels are absent Mass of meconium on the right side of the abdomen is mixed with gas – Soap bubble / Ground glass appearance (Characteristic appearance) Investigation of choice: Water-soluble contrast enema Management: Simple evacuation of meconium with irrigation of proximal and distal bowel with normal saline or 4% acetylcysteine. Named surgeries: Paul Mikulicz Double barrel ileostomy Bishop-Koop’s distal chimney ileostomy Santulli’s proximal chimney ileostomy Sigmoid volvulus (Option A): X-ray abdomen shows a coffee bean appearance of bowel loops . Hirschsprung disease (Option B): The baby presents with bilious vomiting, failure to pass meconium in the first 48 hours of life, abdominal distention, and no stool in the rectal vault. Plain x-ray shows small bowel obstruction. Duodenal atresia (Option C) : The baby will present with bilious vomiting, the X-ray abdomen shows a double bubble sign .

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the meconium plug are false?

options.A: Associated with hypothyroidism and cystic fibrosis
options.B: X-ray of the abdomen shows the corkscrew's appearance
options.C: Water-soluble contrast enema is used for diagnosis and therapeutic purposes.
options.D: It is mostly seen in preterm infants.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) X-ray of the abdomen shows the corkscrew's appearance Explanation: X-ray of the abdomen - the meconium plug normally presents as dilated bowel loops. Corkscrew appearance on X-ray is usually seen in midgut volvulus. Meconium plug: It is a manifestation of Meconium syndrome It leads to large bowel obstruction Most commonly seen in preterm infants (Option D) Generalized abdominal distension Associated with: Maternal diabetes, hypothyroidism, cystic fibrosis (Option A) Diagnosis: On abdominal X-ray - Dilated bowel loops can be observed. Water soluble contrast enema- contrast is hypertonic, and it attracts water in the lumen, as a result of which the patient passes the plug. Hence, the investigation is both diagnostic & therapeutic (Option C) . Water-soluble contrast enema → Passage of meconium plug → Relief of obstruction. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 918.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with recurrent chest infections and dyspnea. Chest CT reveals a 5 cm, well-defined, fluid-filled cystic lesion in the right paratracheal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bronchogenic cyst Explanation: The patient's presentation with recurrent chest infections and dyspnea, along with the CT findings of a well-defined, fluid-filled cystic lesion in the paratracheal region, strongly suggests a bronchogenic cyst . Key features of bronchogenic cysts include: Congenital malformation arising from abnormal budding of the tracheobronchial tree Usually located in the mediastinum (65-90%), particularly in the paratracheal or carinal region Can also occur within the lung parenchyma (15-20%) Typically filled with mucoid material Often asymptomatic, but can cause symptoms due to compression of surrounding structures Symptoms may include cough, dyspnea, chest pain, or recurrent infections On CT, appear as well-defined, fluid-filled cystic lesions Pulmonary sequestration (Option A) is incorrect as sequestrations typically present as solid masses with their own blood supply, not as fluid-filled cysts. Pericardial cyst (Option C) is incorrect as these are typically located in the right cardiophrenic angle and are less likely to cause recurrent infections. Hydatid cyst (Option D) is incorrect as these are parasitic cysts, usually found in the liver or lung parenchyma, and would have a different appearance on CT. Reference: Sabiston's Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page, 1591.

questions.question: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done, as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis you suspect?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Jejunoileal atresia Explanation: The given image shows a triple-bubble appearance which is suggestive of jejunoileal atresia. Classification of jejunoileal atresia: Types Feature Type 1 Membranous atresia with intact bowel mesentery Type 2 With an atretic cord between two blind ends of the bowel with intact mesentery Type 3a Complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap Type 3b An apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap Type 4 Multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance Clinical features: Bilious vomiting within the first day of life. Vomiting is more prominent in proximal obstruction. Abdominal distension is more common in distal obstruction. Management: IV fluids and IV antibiotics Proximal nasogastric decompression Exploratory laparotomy- resection of atretic segment+anastomosis Radiological features of similar conditions: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option B) :

questions.question: On observing the following finding in the X-ray of a baby with a history of Down’s syndrome, what is the most likely diagnosis you would suspect?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Duodenal atresia Explanation: The presence of a double-bubble sign on a plain abdominal radiograph is suggestive of duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distension, usually present within the 1st day of life. Conditions associated with duodenal atresia are Down syndrome, Annular pancreas, malrotation, biliary atresia, polyhydramnios, and prematurity. Types of duodenal

questions.question: An 8-week-old infant is diagnosed with type 3 biliary atresia. The surgical team is planning the most appropriate intervention for this patient. Which of the following describes the preferred surgical approach for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Kasai porto-enterostomy Explanation: Treatment of choice for biliary atresia, specifically for type 2 or above is, Kasai porto-enterostomy. Biliary atresia Treatment Exploratory laparotomy Intra-operative Cholecysto-cholangiogram To confirm the diagnosis, Demonstrate fibrotic biliary remnant Define absent proximal & distal bile duct patency For Type 1- Roux-en-Y jejunal anastomosis For Type 2 and above- Kasai Porto-enterostomy (TOC) Liver transplantation may be required after 3 months. Kasai portoenterostomy Removal of gallbladder and bile duct in case of progressive obliteration Division of jejunum, distal part taken, and proximal part anastomosed into the side of the jejunum Postoperative drug therapy UDCA (Facilitates bile flow) Methylprednisolone (anti-inflammatory agent) TMP-SMX (For antimicrobial prophylaxis) Postoperative Complications Most common: Cholangitis Prognosis No medical treatment can reverse the process of biliary atresia If Surgery is not performed, death occurs within 2 years Surgery should be done within 60 days of birth for better outcomes and survival 30% of patients undergoing Portoenterostomy before 60 days of age have long-term successful survival & don't require liver transplantation Liver Transplantation (Option A): While liver transplantation may eventually be necessary for some patients, it is not the first-line treatment, especially within the first 3 months of life. Choledochoenterostomy (Option C): Choledochoenterostomy is not a suitable treatment option for optimal outcomes. Conservative management with ursodeoxycholic acid (Option D): While UDCA is mentioned as part of postoperative management, it is not a substitute for surgical intervention. Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 8th Edition, Page, 630-631. Bailey & Love Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1241

questions.question: A 3-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with persistent jaundice and pale, clay-colored stools. The parents report that the baby is not gaining weight as expected. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced and the liver is palpable 2 cm below the right costal margin. Which of the following diagnostic tests would be most specific for confirming the suspected diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Intraoperative cholangiogram Explanation: The given clinical history of persistent jaundice in an infant with clay-coloured stools with palpable hepatomegaly is suggestive of biliary atresia . The gold standard test for the diagnosis of Biliary atresia in pediatric patients is intraoperative cholangiogram/ peroperative cholangiogram. Clinical Features and Diagnostic Modalities for Biliary Atresia Clinical Features Obstructive Jaundice at birth or some days after birth Passage of acholic pale grey stools (due to obstructed bile flow) Failure to thrive Signs and symptoms of portal hypertension & hepatic failure (if diagnosis or treatment is delayed) In 25% of cases - Associated malformations (Polysplenia, Malrotation, Preduodenal Portal Vein, Intrahepatic vena cava) Pathological Hallmarks Bile duct proliferation Severe cholestasis with plugging Inflammatory cell infiltrate Diagnosis Gold standard: Intraoperative/perioperative cholangiogram / cholecystocholangiogram (Option D) USG Findings: Gallbladder is shrunken, CBD is not visible (Option A) USG Signs: Gallbladder Ghost triad, triangular cord sign Hepatobiliary scintigraphy: Uptake into the liver without any flow into the duodenum/excretion of radiotracer into the intestine (Option C) CECT (Option B) is not the primary imaging modality used for the diagnosis of biliary atresia. Reference: Pubmed

questions.question: A 6-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice and acholic stools. After initial workup, a congenital hepatobiliary disorder is suspected. Intraoperative cholangiography reveals complete obliteration of the common bile duct, cystic duct, and hepatic duct up to the porta hepatis. Based on the Kasai Classification, which type of this condition does this infant have?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Type 3 Explanation: The infant's age, persistent jaundice, acholic stools, and the cholangiographic findings of complete biliary obstruction up to the porta hepatis all point to the diagnosis of biliary atresia. Definition Progressive obliteration of both intrahepatic & extrahepatic bile ducts Incidence 1:1000 live births Clinical Significance Most common indication of pediatric liver transplantation Pathological Hallmarks Bile duct proliferation Severe cholestasis with plugging Inflammatory cell infiltrate Disease Progression Progresses to: Cirrhosis Portal hypertension Hepatic failure Kasai Classification Type 1: Common bile duct (CBD) is obliterated with patent proximal bile duct & cystic duct (Option A) Type 2A: Characterized by atresia of Common hepatic duct (CHD) with patent cystic duct & CBD (Option B) Type 2B: Characterized by obliteration of CHD, Cystic duct & CBD (Option C) Type 3 (MC type): Atresia of CBD, cystic duct & hepatic duct up to Porta hepatis (responsible > 90% of the cases) (Option D) Reference: SRB Manual of Surgery, 8th Edition, Page, 630-631

questions.question: A newborn is diagnosed with Type A Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). The surgical team is discussing treatment options based on the gap between the proximal and distal ends of the esophagus. On further investigations, the gap is considerably larger. Which of the following will be the correct management for this patient?

options.B: Feeding gastrostomy followed by tension free Esophago-Esophagostomy
options.C: Excision of fistula tract + Tension-free esophago-esophagostomy.
options.D: Excision of fistula tract + repair of the defect.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Feeding gastrostomy followed by tension free Esophago-Esophagostomy of the esophagus. If the gap is large, feeding gastrostomy followed by tension-free Esophago-Esophagostomy is done. Tracheoesophageal Fistula (TEF) Treatment Protocol A: Esophageal atresia (EA) without tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF); B: Proximal TEF with distal EA; C: Distal TEF with proximal EA; D: Proximal and distal TEF; E: TEF without EA ′′ H"-type TEF. Protocol Confirm diagnosis of TEF Determine the type of TEF (A, B, C, D, or E) Assess for associated anomalies (VACTERL) Diagnosis Inability to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach, with coiling in the esophagus suggests esophageal atresia (EA) Presence of gas in GIT below the diaphragm is suggestive of TEF For type E or H-type fistula diagnosis is confirmed by: Tracheo-bronchoscopy (for the evaluation of the trachea) Upper GI endoscopy (For the assessment of the esophagus) Surgical Management For Type A TEF (Isolated esophageal atresia without TEF): a. For small gap: (Option A) Perform tension-free Esophago-Esophagostomy Suture proximal and distal ends b. For large gap: Perform feeding gastrostomy Follow with delayed tension-free Esophago-Esophagostomy For Types B, C, and D TEF (TEF with esophageal atresia): (Option C) Excision of fistula tract Perform tension-free esophago-esophagostomy For Type E TEF (TEF without esophageal atresia): (Option D) Excision of fistula tract Repair of the defect Prognosis Mortality of TEF depends on the abnormalities: Cardiac defects Chromosomal abnormalities

questions.question: A newborn male presents with continuous drooling of saliva from the mouth and regurgitation of feeds given orally. When attempting to pass a nasogastric tube, the physician notices that it coils in the esophagus and cannot be passed into the stomach. X-ray reveals the presence of gas in the gastrointestinal tract below the diaphragm. Further evaluation reports the presence of cardiovascular abnormality. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Explanation: The clinical scenario likely suggests the presence of a tracheo-esophageal fistula . The associated abnormalities are called VACTERL abnormalities, among which VSD is the most common cardiac abnormality. Tracheoesophageal fistula A: Esophageal atresia (EA) without tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF); B: Proximal TEF with distal EA; C: Distal TEF with proximal EA; D: Proximal and distal TEF; E: TEF without EA ′′ H"-type TEF. Definition Fistula: Abnormal communication between 2 epithelialized surfaces TEF: Abnormal communication between trachea & esophagus Association Esophageal atresia Classification Type A: Isolated esophageal atresia without TEF Type B: Esophageal atresia with proximal TEF Type C: Esophageal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula (Most common type) Type D: Esophageal atresia with both proximal + distal esophageal fistula (Least common type) Type E: TEF without esophageal atresia or H-shaped fistula Risk Factor Maternal history of Polyhydramnios Clinical Features Continuous drooling of saliva from the mouth Regurgitation of feeds given orally If food or saliva enters the trachea: Choking Coughing Cyanosis Dyspnea Diagnosis Inability to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach, with coiling in the esophagus suggests esophageal atresia (EA) Presence of gas in GIT below the diaphragm is suggestive of TEF Associated Abnormalities (VACTERL) V ertebral body segmentation defect A nal atresia C ardiovascular anomalies (VSD, PDA): M/C anomaly. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): M/C among cardiovascular defects TE F R enal abnormality (Unilateral renal agenesis) L imb anomalies (Radial ray hypoplasia) PDA (Option B) is another cardiac abnormality seen in TEF. However, TOF (Option C) and ASD (Option D) are not associated with TEF.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion. Chest X-ray shows an elevated left hemidiaphragm. Further imaging reveals thinning and upward displacement of the left hemidiaphragm without any defect. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Plication of the diaphragm Explanation: The clinical scenario describes eventration of the diaphragm , a condition characterized by abnormal elevation of part or all of the diaphragm due to thinning or absence of muscle fibers . In this case, the patient is symptomatic with progressive dyspnea, indicating the need for surgical intervention. Plication of the diaphragm is the most appropriate management. Types of eventration: 1. Congenital: Present at birth, often due to incomplete muscularization 2. Acquired: Secondary to phrenic nerve injury, neuromuscular disorders, or trauma Treatment depends on the severity of symptoms: Asymptomatic cases: Observation and follow-up Symptomatic cases: Surgical intervention Surgical options: Plication of the diaphragm: The most common surgical approach Involves folding and suturing the thinned diaphragm to reduce its surface area and lower its position Can be done via open thoracotomy or minimally invasive techniques (thoracoscopy or laparoscopy) Mesh reinforcement: Used in cases with severe thinning or small defects Observation and follow-up (Option A) is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic and requires intervention. Mesh repair (Option C) is incorrect as there is no defect mentioned, only thinning and displacement. Pneumoperitoneum (Option D) induction is incorrect as this is not a standard treatment for diaphragmatic eventration.

questions.question: A 20-year-old female presents with recurrent hemoptysis. CT angiography reveals a dense lesion in the left lower lobe with arterial supply from the descending thoracic aorta. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Intralobar pulmonary sequestration Explanation: In this case, the patient's age (20 years), presentation with hemoptysis, and CT findings of a lesion within the lung parenchyma with systemic arterial supply are all consistent with intralobar pulmonary sequestration . Pulmonary sequestration is a congenital malformation where a segment of lung tissue is separated from the normal bronchial tree and receives its blood supply from systemic circulation, typically the descending thoracic aorta . There are two types of pulmonary sequestration: Intralobar sequestration (ILS) Extralobar sequestration (ELS) More common (75-90% of cases) Located within normal lung tissue Shares pleural covering with the normal lung Usually diagnosed in adolescents or young adults Common symptoms: recurrent pneumonia, hemoptysis Venous drainage is typically to the pulmonary veins Less common (10-25% of cases) Separate from normal lung tissue with its own pleural covering Usually diagnosed in infancy or early childhood Often associated with other congenital anomalies Venous drainage is typically to the systemic veins (Azygos, Hemiazygos vein, Venacava) Extralobar pulmonary sequestration (Option B) is incorrect as ELS is usually diagnosed earlier in life and is less likely to present with hemoptysis. Bronchogenic cyst (Option C) is incorrect as these are fluid-filled cysts without systemic arterial supply. Congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (Option D) is incorrect as these typically do not have a systemic arterial supply and present differently on imaging.
